The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Heather Fosburgh
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  Heather
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  Heather Fosburgh
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  heather fosburgh
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  I interacted most closely with Heather Fosburgh with regards of international development work. She was a great resource to have in class.
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  Heather Fosburgh

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Given the context of the class, sometimes there coursework was heavy with deadlines and sometimes it was normal in the reading and written assignments. I think it's hard in general to assess this class as a regular class with feedback from the professors with our groups and what was taught-which is not so much specific concepts or theories, but about working in the real world, in developing countries, and the professionalism involved. What we learned from our projects was primarily self-taught, which is another great skill to havein the workforce.
This course was absolutely fantastic!!

On top of the class we had a DILS creole teacher that prepared us to the language skills necessary to be able to perform our duties while in Haiti. Mr. Robert Lamothe also trained us in general Haitian culture, history, cuisine and architecture. He was a great addition to the class.

This was an amazing course that brought together students from varying backgrounds, disciplines, and schools. I learned so much and really appreciated all of the work put into organizing the experience in Haiti.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspects of this course was the interdisciplinary fields applied to the problem in Haiti. The small class size facilitated the flow of conversation and Gordon and Gary were great instructors in that sense. As the TA Heather balanced out the instruction and was essential for the coordination during class and while in Haiti. The class application of working on projects in collaboration for an organization demonstrated the need for professionalism without being too formal about grading, etc, which is much different than other classes I have taken. I think it's partially because the majority of the class had some work experience prior to coming back to school and so it didn't need to be stated I(for the most part).During Haiti, the ability to visit different parts of the country and compare the different hospital and business models allowed me to see how different organizations work in different capacities.Reading books on Haiti was also a great way to supplement my knowledge of the country and the people there.Lastly, dinner/snacks was also great to have.
The trip was fantastic! I also really appreciate the leadership style and flexibility of the course instructors.
The best aspect of this course was the field trip to Haiti. The second best aspect of this class was the book assignments. The third best aspect of this class was the Haitian creole lessons.
Opportunity to travel in Haiti and discuss in depth the complexities of overseas NGO/humanitarian efforts.Students from 3 different schools (Forestry, Public Health&Nursing)
Discussion of the role of NGOs and government in development, implementation barriers in development, data driven presentations, the USAID and professor guest speakers

The best part of the course was having the opportunity to work with an NGO "client" in Haiti. By far the richest part of the learning experience was to coordinate back-and-forwarth with the NGO before the trip in trying to hone in on specific project ideas, then spending time with the NGO staff during the trip, and after returning, producing deliverables for the client based on what they had said they wanted and on our experiences in Haiti.I also really enjoyed having done my independent study on agroforestry in the fall and then being able to apply what I had learned in an on-the-ground experience.Also, the class was a wonderful, supportive, kind learning environment. The instructors and all the students are wonderful people who all got along, so the class and the trip was really fun!
The trip was the highlight of my semester - extremely well laid out and a wonderful group of students and faculty.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The professors were in charge of 2 groups each; however, I felt that that they did not spread their time evenly between the two groups, especially during the trip in Haiti. They each had their own interest and stuck with those two groups while the other two groups were more often left on their own.Organization was well done considering the change in the course and the lack of syllabus. However, I think that groups should start even sooner in the projects if it is possible. In the real world you are confronted with last minute reports, etc so perhaps it isn't too different in that regard. However, as students, sometimes it's a real struggle to complete work so last minute.
none
I would try to schedule the book reports along the semester and not cluster them into one single class. It felt like there were too many things happening at once during the same class.

More materials in general need to be brought into the course in an organized way before the trip. For example, it would have been great to see Baseball in the Time of Cholera before going. It's perhaps hard to do this because of the groups - but perhaps a list of literature can be created for each group before the class starts.

In preparation for the Haiti trip, I feel that either the instructors should have provided more guidance to the students in terms of the kind of projects to do OR that the instructors should have allowed the students to steer the interactions with the NGO clients from the get-go. I remember the first 2 or 3 weeks where we were told to not contact the NGO directly, which left us confused during those weeks of how to even begin thinking about our project. Once we were allowed to communicate with the NGO directly, it was a great learning experience to navigate that relationship and expectations on our own.Also, the lectures leading up to the trip could have been more rich in content to help us better prepare for the trip.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: it was effective.
If we take the lab section as the field trip I have to say the lectures were very relevant.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: she was very organized, thorough, and knowledgable. the only improvement I would suggest is if she could send the readings out a little earlier (usually we would get them the day of class).
Heather was well-organized and very supportive throughout the course.

Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  Heather is great at organizing and coordinating readings, speakers, and the activities involved with the trip from forms, passports,etc. She also has a lot of international experience that enriches the experience of the class.At times it seemed like it would have been nice to have a second TA in the class to help. This class was smaller than last year, but given my other comment about the lack of support from the professors during the field trip, it would have been nice to have a fourth person so that every group had at least one Yale affiliated instructor/TA with them. This would also be beneficial during class time when questions arose during group meetings.
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  It was helpful that she had been a student in the course last year and had traveled to Haiti before.
Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  Strengths: organized, involved, reliable

Instructor: Heather Elizabeth Fosburgh  Heather was very well organized and did a great job of keeping people on task with preparing for the trip. There were only a couple times that I was confused about what was going on as we prepared for the trip. For instance, it would have been a bit better if the students could have received some of the information with more notice (like a packing list, the trip itinerary, etc).

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm a graduate student at the School of Nursing. This course provided me with a big picture understanding of the health and well-being of individuals living in extreme poverty. It was possibly the most useful experience i've had in grad school to date.

I'm concentrating in international environmental policy. This class was really important to have a broader view and understanding of the international development cooperation or international aid programs. How they've worked in the past and present in Haiti. Having Haiti as the case study was really intersting due to the unique nature and un-replicability of the Haitian status quo in the world.
Provides a valuable and high quality service learning opportunity that allows the students to learn much more than they could by simply reading and discussing in the classroom
I'm interested in sustainable forestry in Latin America/the Caribbean, so it was a really rich experience for me to get to work with and support HTRIP in their agroforestry efforts.
I really enjoyed the health-focused aspect of the trip to Haiti

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in global health and wanted a different applicable approach to global health. This class offers the professional experience in a learning environment on public health and related environmental issues. I really wanted that interdisciplinary experience often lacking in research only experiences. We also had a chance to discuss the problems in Haiti from all angles-social, political, historical, ethical, etc....

So many reasons. I wanted to learn about health and health care outside of YSN. I wanted to learn from other disciplines. I wanted to learn about the Haitian culture. I wanted to learn about how development affects a population's health outcomes.
I was really interested in having the experience of going to Haiti to see firsthanded the efforts and effects of NGOs in the reconstruction of the country after the earthquake.
An interest in Haiti and desire to take a class in a school different from my current program.
I wanted an on-the-ground experience in supporting forestry/agroforestry projects in the Caribbean/Latin America.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. The only expectations I really had were the real application of my own knowledge to public health and environmental problems.
Yes.
Yes, I feel I'm more versed in Haitian reality and the work of the international community in Haiti.
Yes

Yes, I gained field research, survey development, group leadership and teamwork skills. Knowledge gained spanned many disciplines that were important to bring together to understand the larger context. I gained more out of the course than I expected - especially in relation to developing my career goals.
Yes, I learned a ton about Haiti and agroforestry in Haiti, as well as gaining valuable experience in working with an NGO client.
Yes, I learned an incredible amount and gained exposure to a country I otherwise would not have had the chance to study.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: great way to engage with a specific topic

Yes. My group was great. I think I had a great group with a good balance of personalities and work ethic. Everyone did their work and contributed to the project. We also all brought in our own experiences to the assigned project and played upon our strengths to move the project forward.Disadvantages-we often did not have the same schedule and finding time to meet was often difficult outside the classroom.
Advantage includes learning from other disciplines. Disadvantages includes trying to find the time to get together when we are all in different schools and have vastly different schedules.
My group was excellent. We had a pool of talented people with diverse backgrounds that provided the tools for the "consulting/learning" experience while in Haiti.
Good opportunity to learn to work in groups. The final report we compiled was a good exercise in group writing.
Advantage: learning from each other and using our own strengthsDisadvantage: hard to coordinate effectively and perhaps not pressured enough to do so
Our group was really wonderful, each person contributing in great and unique ways. I learned so much from by otherteam members.
The multidisciplinary nature of the students in the course made it a wonderful group of people to work with. Group work all went smoothly.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's not your typical organized class-even if you have taken other practicum-like classes. The instructors are great and really want you to have a dialogue about the projects you are working on the and the issues in performing the projects. It reminds you of the professionalism you should have and you learn a lot independently. I think that these differ much more than other public health courses where there are stricter guidelines that takes away from the independent learning experience and the discussions you should be having in class.
Enjoy it while it lasts!!
Put a lot of effort in learning creole,your experience will be that much incredible if you're able to communicate without a translator.
Be prepared to change your original project idea(s)/plan(s)!
Read, read, read before you go. Even if you're finding the readings yourself or saving things to take and read while you're there.

This is mostly a self-motivated class. If you want it to be a rich experience, it can be, but you have to make your group project really meaningful by connecting with the NGO counterparts, figuring out their expectations and how you can contribute, and setting a high bar for yourself.
